Title: Wealth shown to scale
Data: The wealth data of the richest people in USA.
ShortDes: It encodes the wealth data of the median US household income, Jeff Bezos, and the richest 400 Americans using a linear scale of $1 per pixel. Each data item is represented by a rectangle. All data items are lined up horizontally. audience use keyboard interaction to scroll from left to right to fully view each data item. There is a scroll bar in the bottom such that the audience can Jump or skip the scrolling.
Note: Compare wealth with cancer curation fee

Title: 8 BILLION people in perspective
Data: The world pupulation when it reaches 8 billion.
ShortDes: The video presents the world population. A camera with the overhead angle moving backward reveals 3D human models that represent all humans forming a giant square. There are models of city buildings and famous landmarks like Eiffel Tower scaled to compare with the human crowds. The video ends with an overview of the square.

Title: Risk, cycling and denominator neglect
Data: Number of bike tirps and trip incidents in 2012 in Greater London.
ShortDes: In this visualization, every human icons represents a trip a bicycle. It shows all bicycle journeys made in 2012 in Greater London. 25,000 trips on a bicycle are grouped as a block, the average number of trips made every hour in Greater London. Every 13 blocks are grouped in a larger block, representing 325,000 journeys which averagely has 1 serious injury. The audience can scrolled down to see the whole visualization.

Title: Yale's $32 Billion endowment compared to its paltry $13 million contribution to the city of New Haven
Data: Yale's $32 Billion endowment compared to its paltry $13 million contribution to the city of New Haven.
ShortDes: The visualization is a bidirectional bar chart on the ground. One side of it is the bar that represents Yale's $32 billion endowment, while the other side is the bar that represents Yale's paltry $13 million contribution to the city of New Haven. The audiences walk along side the bar to sense how long the bar is.

Title: The historical cost of light
Data: How long people need to work to afford the cost of an hour's light in different centries.
ShortDes: Each pixel the audience scroll through is equivalent to a second of work for an average waged worker in America. The audience will try how long they need to scroll to gain an hour of lumination based on the salary in 2020,1800s, and 2000BC.

Title: Hiking path of the solar system
Data: The sizes of planets in the solar system and the distances between them.
ShortDes: The path is designed on a scale of 1:1 billion and thus offers a clear representation of the sizes and distances in the solar system . One meter of the model corresponds to one million kilometers in reality. The planetary path includes not only the planets Mercury , Venus , Earth , Mars , Jupiter , Saturn , Uranus and Neptune , but also the dwarf planets Ceres and Pluto .
Note: The data be understood through lengthy is the distance

Title: Trail of Time
Data: The time of the Grand Canyon's geologic history mapped into walking distances in the Grand Canyon.
ShortDes: "The start of the Trail of Time is at Yavapai Geology Museum, a half hour walk from Mather Point and the Canyon View Visitor Center." Visitors "will start by walking the 'Million Year Trail', which transitions from human time scales to geologic ones. The 'Million Year Trail' is immediately followed by the main Trail of Time where each meter equals one million years of Grand Canyon's geologic history. This fully accessible one hour walking trip provides breath taking vistas of Grand Canyon and allows you to ponder and understand the depths of geologic space and time."

Title: The Fallen of World War II
Data: The number of death caused by World War II in different countries.
ShortDes: Starting from 05:43, the camera moves up to reveal a long bar representing the death number of the Russian military during WWII. When the camerve moves up, a zoom out movement is accompanying.

Title: The Deep Sea
Data: How deep different marine animals live in the sea.
ShortDes: As the audience scroll down, the audience see the cutout images of marine animals at deeper level of the sea. A horizental line at the bottom part with a number show to suggest how many meters deep the position of the line represents.
Note: lengthy pan is for depth of sea, but vis is for both depth and animals

Title: The actual number of Americans jailed or imprisoned, about 2.3 million
Data: Statistics related to Americans in jailed.
ShortDes: In the website, every human icon represents an America in jail (the collected data time is unsure). As the audience scroll down, the accumulative number of people icons has been shown is updated at the right top corner of the website. The website also overlay related statistics, facts and charts in front of the human icon background to give more details.

Title: A VR 360 video case from an experiment
Data: The amount of tea production by countries.
ShortDes: A 360° VR video where viewers explore a 3D bar chart from a spaceship. Bars, scaled as 1x1m tea cubes, rise in real-world proportions. The ship moves dynamically, including upward, for optimal viewing.

Title: Timeline-of-the-universe-from-the-big-bang-to-the-death-of-our-sun
Data: The time of both past and forthcoming events in our Universe, from the Big Bang to the death of our Sun.
ShortDes: The timeline is layout vertically. As the audience scrolls down, diifferent events show up.

Title: All People on One Page
Data: The number of people living on Earth.
ShortDes: Each human icon in the website represents one human. At the top is the estimated number of people living on Earth, updated in real-time. The website adding new icons at the top from let to right. The audience scrolls down and left/right to look through all icons. When the mouse is hovered in an icon, a tooltip next to the cursor shows the total number of people born until that icon is generated.
Note: The "Watch as we increase" option is related to Real-Time Data Visualization

Title: Death in Syria
Data: The number of people killed in the four-and-a-half-year Syrian civil war (reported at Sept.14, 2015).
ShortDes: Each red dot represents a peron got killed in the war.

Title: 7 billion people on 1 page
Data: Number of people in the world when it reaches seven billion.
ShortDes: Each human icon in the website represents one human. Different colors represents different continents. The audience can scroll vertically and horizontally to look through all icons.

Title: Walk approach to and away from a screen
Data: General
ShortDes: Showing data in a screen. "Small data visible up closer; large data only visible from far away"

Title: Take an Elevator
Data: General
ShortDes: The viewer is taking an elevator that has a transparent window. Looking out the window there is a chart painted on the wall. As elevator moves up, differents part of the chart are revealed.

Title: Peephole interaction
Data: General
ShortDes: The viewer is moving a phone around to scan a wall, and different parts of the chart shows up in the phone's screen like a peephole interaction.

Title: Adapting avatar size to scale of data: move slow for small values and fater for lager ones.
VR roller coaster
Data: Wealth
ShortDes: In a VR  experience, viewers take a roller coster. The length of a roller coster represents the common amount of wealth of different social classes. The larger amount of wealth correspond to larger size of a loop or more numbers of loops.

Title: Spaceship traveling in VR to see planets
Data: Planet distances
ShortDes: In a VR experience, the viewers take a spaceship to go to traveling between planets to understand their distances (scaled).

Title: Hiking or cycling with AR to show planets
Data: Planet distances

Title: Sand represents population and drop through different diameters
Tissue paper box
Data: Waste data

Title: Roll of toilet paper
Data: What is the size of different digital media in KB?
ShortDes:
"I start with a sheet representing 60 MB and cut it in 2 several times to give different sizes until I get to an email without attachments.

Then I ask the assembly how many sheets would be needed for 1 hour of video on Netflix in HD. I unroll and give the answer, stopping at 50 sheets (3 GB)."

Title: All of the World’s Money and Markets in One Visualization
Data: Wealth data
ShortDes: In the visualization, each square represents $100 billion. It shows the world's money and market distributted in different categories like countries, continents, sectors and so on.

Title: Earth surrounding by money in VR
Data: Wealth data
ShortDes: In a VR experience, the money of rich people is layout as circles surrounding a planet. The users would take a spaceship to walk through those circles.

Title: Biking around the planets in VR
Data: Sizes of planets
ShortDes: In a VR experience, the viewers ride a bike o go a full round outside a planet the size of which is scaled.

Title: If the moon were one pixel
Data: Planet distances and sizes
ShortDes: Moon is scaled as a pixel in the screen. Based on this scale, the visualization presents planets in the solar system from left to right. The users can horizontally scroll the website to examine the distances between different planets and their sizes.

Title: O cálculo de uma tragédia (The calculation of a tragedy)
Data: Covid-19 death number in Brazil
ShortDes: Each dot represents a person who died from COVID-19 in Brazil. The dots are arranged in chronological order, grouped by the day each death occurred. From top to bottom, the number of dots represents the number of deaths as time progresses. The visualization also overlays the figures of cars and trains to illustrate the scale of the tragedy, showing how many vehicles would be needed to accommodate the number of people who died during certain periods.

Title: What if I told you: you eat 3496 litres of water
Data: Litres of water for producing food (e.g.,  to produce 1 kilogram of boneless beef we need 15400 litres of water)
ShortDes: The icons of 15400 bottles that represent 15400 liters of water are stacked up to represent a large wall of bottles.

Title: 500,000 lives lost
Data: COVID-19 death unmber in USA
ShortDes: Each dot represents a person who died from COVID-19 in USA. The dots are arranged in chronological order, grouped by the day each death occurred. From top to bottom, the number of dots represents the number of deaths as time progresses. On the top left, there is a mini-view of the visualization and the current position where the viewers are.

Title: Sea level rise by the numbers
Data: The 75.6 trillion gallons of meltwater from Greenland’s ice sheet between 2002 and 2017
ShortDes: The visualizations use a pictogram of Olympic-size swimming pool to represent 660,000 gallons of water, 1,000 pools, or 1 million pools. Only in the last case, it is possible to show how much swiming pools should be presented to represent the 76.6 trillion gallons of metlwater.
